title: 103_hr3898
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds that the New Bedford National Historic Landmark District and associated historic sites are significant for illustrating the history of whaling in the United States, particularly in New Bedford, the 19th-century capital of the world's whaling industry. These historic resources offer opportunities for interpreting the industry's impact on the economic, social, and environmental history of the country. The Act aims to preserve and interpret resources related to whaling history in the United States, collaborate with local organizations, and provide educational opportunities for the public. The Act defines "park" as the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. The Act establishes the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park. The New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park is established to preserve districts, structures, and relics associated with the history of whaling in America. The boundaries of the park are depicted on a map and include the New Bedford National Historic Landmark District. The New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park includes the National Historic Landmark Schooner Ernestina and specific land areas within New Bedford. The boundaries are defined by landmarks and streets. The Secretary may also assist in interpretation and preservation efforts. The Secretary may assist in interpreting and preserving specific landmarks within the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park, including the southwest corner of the State Pier, Waterfront Park, the Rotch-Jones-Duff House and Garden Museum, the Wharfinger Building, and the Bourne Counting House. The administration of the park is outlined in Section 4. The park shall be administered by the Secretary in accordance with applicable laws, including the National Park Service Act. The Secretary may enter into cooperative agreements for the park's preservation and development, with funds to be expended in a specific ratio. The Secretary is authorized to accept donations from non-Federal sources for the purposes of the Act. Any payment made under a cooperative agreement must be used in accordance with the Act, or the United States has the right to reimbursement. There is a limitation on the funds that can be appropriated. The Secretary may acquire lands for the park by donation, exchange, lease, or purchase with funds, with limitations on funds not exceeding 50% of total costs or $300,000 annually. Acquisition of lands owned by the State of Massachusetts requires donation, while lands not owned by the state need owner consent. The Secretary may acquire lands for the park through donation, exchange, lease, or purchase with funds not exceeding 50% of total costs or $300,000 annually. Acquisition of lands owned by the State of Massachusetts requires donation, while lands not owned by the state need owner consent. The Secretary may also accept donated funds, property, and services to carry out the Act. The Secretary must submit a general management plan for the park within two years of the Act's enactment and implement it. Appropriations of up to $10,400,000 are authorized for construction and facilities. AN ACT to establish the New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park in New Bedford, Massachusetts.
